elements.content: A novel Zn­(II) coordination polymer based on 5-(3-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole-2-thiol (Hpzt), namely [Zn­(pzt)2] n or Zn-CP, was synthesized by two different synthetic methods. The bulk polycrystals and single crystals of Zn-CP were obtained by a conventional solvothermal method at 90 °C. Zn-CP exhibits a two-dimensional (2D) coordination network that contains the uncoordinated Lewis basic sites within each layer. Interestingly, a simple and environmentally friendly sonochemical synthesis of the Zn-CP in an aqueous media could be performed at room temperature. The optimal synthetic conditions were studied. The uniform microplates of Zn-CP were obtained within 30 min with the addition of pyridine, acting as a size modulator and a deprotonating reagent. The influence of the amount of the modulator and the sonication time on the crystal size was investigated. Moreover, a Zn-CP suspension in an ethanolic media has been used as a luminescence sensor for the detection of nitroaromatic compounds. It shows highly selective and sensitive sensing of 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) through a quenching (turn-off) process under UV light. Also, the Zn-CP microplates show higher dispersibility and a more stable suspension in comparison to those of bulk products, causing an increase of the luminescent sensing performance for TNP.

elements.content: A new Zn­(II) coordination polymer (Zn-CP) was synthesized by solvothermal and sonochemical methods. The uniform Zn-CP microplates were simply obtained under mild ultrasonic conditions in an aqueous medium. Zn-CP exhibits highly selective quenching for TNP with a high quenching constant and low detection limit.

elements.content: Coordination polymers (CPs) are crystalline organic–inorganic hybrid materials constructed from the coordination bonds between metal centers and molecular linkers. During the last two decades, CPs have been some of the most attractive materials for various applications such as adsorption and separation, catalysis, magnetism, sensing, and so on, due to their fascinating structure-dependent multifunctional properties that can be deliberately fabricated and tuned by the different combination of metal ions and organic ligands on a self-assembly process.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers (CPs) are crystalline organic-inorganic hybrid materials constructed from the coordination bonds between metal centers and molecular linkers. During the last two decades, CPs have been some of the most attractive materials for various applications such as adsorption and separation, catalysis, magnetism, sensing, and so on, due to their fascinating structure-dependent multifunctional properties that can be deliberately fabricated and tuned by the different combination of metal ions and organic ligands on a self-assembly process.

elements.content: CPs are commonly prepared by a solvothermal synthesis. In many cases, this method is performed in an organic solvent with high temperature, high pressure, and long reaction time. To reduce the energy consumption and synthetic time, a sonochemical synthesis is more attractive for the preparation of CPs because an ultrasonic apparatus uses a green energy source and is more convenient, cost-effective, environmentally friendly, fast, and straightforward. During an ultrasound irradiation, the acoustic cavitation process, nucleation, growth, and the collapse of bubbles in aquatic ambiance, can generate local hot spots having high temperatures (5000–25000 K) and high pressure (1800 atm) with a very fast cooling and heating rate. These extreme conditions can drive homogeneous nucleation with chemically active reactant species and a substantial decrease in crystallization time, resulting in the formation of micro- or nanostructures within a few minutes. Although a number of the reported CPs have been synthesized by sonochemistry, the construction of a uniform morphology of CPs remains challenging. In order to finely control the size and shape of CPs with a simple and straightforward method, a modulating agent has been used in sonochemistry. As the same chemical functionality of the modulating molecules with the organic linkers of CPs, the coordination ability between the metal ions and the ligands is impeded that regulates the nucleation and crystal growth rates of CPs; thus, a regular micro size and good shape of CPs can be obtained. Furthermore, some modulators can also act as a deprotonating reagent, which can reduce the use of some basic organic solvents such as N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) in the synthetic conditions.

elements.content: As a toxic and explosive pollutant, nitroaromatic compounds (NACs) such as 2,4-dinitrophenol (2,4-DNP), dinitrotoluene (DNT), and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) are high explosives and dangerous energy sources. Among these NACs, 2,4,6-trinitrophenol or TNP is a highly powerful explosive and is commonly used in chemical industries, especially dyes, fireworks, matches, and leather industries. Furthermore, the contamination of TNP in the environment can cause several health issues such as anemia, skin irritation, and abnormal life function, which result from its mutagenic and carcinogenic activities. Although some CPs had been reported for the detection of NACs, the selective sensing of TNP is still challenging. Moreover, many analytical methods have been employed to detect NACs, but they suffer from disadvantages such as time-consumption, high cost, and harsh reaction conditions. Therefore, a simple luminescent method and the development of electron-rich CP-based luminescent sensors with specifically basic sites for enhancing the sensitive and selective detection of electron-deficient acidic TNP within short response times are very important research topics.

elements.content: Encouraged by the combination of these two basic synthetic strategies, we report herein the simple preparation of a new [Zn­(pzt)2] n or Zn-CP, where Hpzt = 5-(3-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole-2-thiol, by solvothermal and sonochemical methods. The simple and environmentally friendly sonochemical synthesis of the uniform microstructure of Zn-CP was developed in aqueous media with the presence of a modulating reagent at room temperature. The resulting strong luminescent Zn-CP microplate that contains uncoordinated basic sites within the layer displayed a high luminescent sensing performance for TNP.

elements.content: All chemicals were purchased and used as received without further purification. The ATR-IR spectra (ATR is attenuated total reflectance) were recorded using a standard Pike ATR cell on a Bruker Tensor 27 FT-IR spectrophotometer in the range 4000–600 cm–1. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurement was performed using a PANalytical EMPYREAN X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα source (λ = 1.5406 Å) in the 2θ range 5–50° with a recording speed of 0.5 s/step. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were collected on a PerkinElmer PE 2400CHNS analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out with a Hitachi STA7200 thermal analyzer at 30–800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 under a nitrogen atmosphere. The sonicator used in this study was an Elmasonic S30H (maximum 280 W at 50 Hz). The scanning electron microscope (SEM) was performed using a SNE-4500 M microscope with gold coating. The luminescence spectra were obtained by using a Shimadzu RF-6000 Spectro fluorophotometer equipped with a continuous Xe lamp at room temperature. The UV–vis spectra in the liquid state were recorded using a Shimadzu UV 2450 spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Methods

All chemicals were purchased and used as received without further purification. The ATR-IR spectra (ATR is attenuated total reflectance) were recorded using a standard Pike ATR cell on a Bruker Tensor 27 FT-IR spectrophotometer in the range 4000-600 cm-1. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurement was performed using a PANalytical EMPYREAN X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα source (λ = 1.5406 Å) in the 2θ range 5-50° with a recording speed of 0.5 s/step. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were collected on a PerkinElmer PE 2400CHNS analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out with a Hitachi STA7200 thermal analyzer at 30-800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 under a nitrogen atmosphere. The sonicator used in this study was an Elmasonic S30H (maximum 280 W at 50 Hz). The scanning electron microscope (SEM) was performed using a SNE-4500 M microscope with gold coating. The luminescence spectra were obtained by using a Shimadzu RF-6000 Spectro fluorophotometer equipped with a continuous Xe lamp at room temperature. The UV-vis spectra in the liquid state were recorded using a Shimadzu UV 2450 spectrometer.

elements.content: The bulk crystals and a single crystal of Zn-CP were prepared by mixing Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0297 g, 0.1 mmol) and Hpzt (0.0178 g, 0.1 mmol) in 4 mL of H2O/ACN/DMF (1/2/1 mL). The solution mixture was placed in a 20 mL glass vial and then sealed and heated at 90 °C for 16 h to obtain pale yellow crystals of Zn-CP. Yield: 0.0117 g, 49.3% (based on Hpzt). Anal. Calcd for ZnC14H8N6O2S2 (fw = 421.75): C, 39.87; H, 1.91; N, 19.93. Found: C, 39.42; H, 1.64; N, 19.62. FT-IR (ATR, cm–1): 1610 (w), 1173 (s), 1123 (w), 1050 (m), 944 (m), 688 (s).
elements.clean_text:
Solvothermal Synthesis of [Zn(pzt)2] n  (Zn-CP)

The bulk crystals and a single crystal of Zn-CP were prepared by mixing Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0297 g, 0.1 mmol) and Hpzt (0.0178 g, 0.1 mmol) in 4 mL of H2O/ACN/DMF (1/2/1 mL). The solution mixture was placed in a 20 mL glass vial and then sealed and heated at 90 °C for 16 h to obtain pale yellow crystals of Zn-CP. Yield: 0.0117 g, 49.3% (based on Hpzt). Anal. Calcd for ZnC14H8N6O2S2 (fw = 421.75): C, 39.87; H, 1.91; N, 19.93. Found: C, 39.42; H, 1.64; N, 19.62. FT-IR (ATR, cm-1): 1610 (w), 1173 (s), 1123 (w), 1050 (m), 944 (m), 688 (s).

elements.content: To prepare a micro-sized Zn-CP, Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0297 g, 0.1 mmol) and Hpzt (0.0178 g, 0.1 mmol) were mixed with 6 mL of water containing the pyridine. The mixture was positioned in an ultrasonic bath, operating at 50 Hz with a maximum power output of 280 W, under atmospheric pressure and ambient temperature. The amount of pyridine and sonication time were varied following the synthetic conditions, as summarized in . After the sonication process, a pale yellow polycrystal of Zn-CP was obtained. Then, the product was filtered off and washed with ethanol to remove the pyridine and dried in the air.
elements.clean_text:
Sonochemical Synthesis of [Zn(pzt)2] n  (Zn-CP)

To prepare a micro-sized Zn-CP, Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0297 g, 0.1 mmol) and Hpzt (0.0178 g, 0.1 mmol) were mixed with 6 mL of water containing the pyridine. The mixture was positioned in an ultrasonic bath, operating at 50 Hz with a maximum power output of 280 W, under atmospheric pressure and ambient temperature. The amount of pyridine and sonication time were varied following the synthetic conditions, as summarized in . After the sonication process, a pale yellow polycrystal of Zn-CP was obtained. Then, the product was filtered off and washed with ethanol to remove the pyridine and dried in the air.

A Bruker D8 Quest PHOTON100 CMOS detector with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation with the APEX2 program was performed to collect the crystallographic data of Zn-CP. The raw data were integrated by the SAINT program and further collected for Lorentz and polarization effects followed by the application of an empirical absorption correction (SADABS). The structure solution was solved by direct methods. Then it was refined by a full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms using the SHELXTL software. All H atoms were placed in ideal positions and refined as riding atoms. Topological analysis was analyzed by the TOPOS program. The crystal data and refinement parameters are summarized in . The details of selected bond lengths and angles for Zn-CP are given in Table S1.

X-ray Data Collection and Structural Refinement Details

A Bruker D8 Quest PHOTON100 CMOS detector with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation with the APEX2 program was performed to collect the crystallographic data of Zn-CP. The raw data were integrated by the SAINT program and further collected for Lorentz and polarization effects followed by the application of an empirical absorption correction (SADABS). The structure solution was solved by direct methods. Then it was refined by a full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms using the SHELXTL software. All H atoms were placed in ideal positions and refined as riding atoms. Topological analysis was analyzed by the TOPOS program. The crystal data and refinement parameters are summarized in . The details of selected bond lengths and angles for Zn-CP are given in Table S1.

To carry out the luminescence titration for TNP, 10 mg of the finely ground Zn-CP was added to 120 mL of ethanol. After the sonication of this mixture at room temperature for 30 min, a suspension of Zn-CP in ethanolic media was obtained. Then 4.5 mL of the Zn-CP suspension was pipetted to a 5 mL volumetric flask; after that a different amount of 1 mM TNP solution was added. The volume of the suspension containing TNP was adjusted to 5 mL by ethanol, giving a different concentration of TNP in the Zn-CP luminescent probe. Finally, this suspension was transferred to a quartz cuvette followed by monitoring emission intensity upon excitation at 387 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Sensing Experiment

To carry out the luminescence titration for TNP, 10 mg of the finely ground Zn-CP was added to 120 mL of ethanol. After the sonication of this mixture at room temperature for 30 min, a suspension of Zn-CP in ethanolic media was obtained. Then 4.5 mL of the Zn-CP suspension was pipetted to a 5 mL volumetric flask; after that a different amount of 1 mM TNP solution was added. The volume of the suspension containing TNP was adjusted to 5 mL by ethanol, giving a different concentration of TNP in the Zn-CP luminescent probe. Finally, this suspension was transferred to a quartz cuvette followed by monitoring emission intensity upon excitation at 387 nm.

elements.content: A single-crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis demonstrates that Zn-CP crystallizes in the monoclinic system with C2/c space group. The crystal data and the refinement details of Zn-CP are given in . There are one Zn­(II) ion and two deprotonated Hpzt ligands in the asymmetric unit. As shown in a, each Zn­(II) resides in a tetrahedral ZnN4 geometry that is constructed from two pyridyl nitrogen atoms and two oxadiazole N-donors from four individual pzt ligands with average Zn–N distances of 1.978(3)–2.000(3) and 2.034(3)–2.054(3) Å for Zn–Noxa and Zn–Npy, respectively. The adjacent Zn­(II) ions are bridged by two μ2-pzt ligands, resulting in 14-membered ring of the Zn­(II) dinuclear unit. Each dinuclear unit is further connected by four adjacent units via four μ2-pzt ligands, generating a 2D layer of Zn-CP in a crystallographic ab plane (b). The shortest Zn···Zn separation within the layers is 7.7229(8) Å. It is intriguingly observed that each pzt displays a similar coordination mode, adopting a bidentate bridging mode of μ2-η1(Noxa):η1(Npy) with dihedral angles between the pyridine and oxadiazole planes of 9.94(11) and 5.07(12) Å. The C–S bond lengths of pzt (C2S1 = 1.661(4) Å and C9S1 = 1.667(4) Å) are shorter than that of the thiolate pzt anion, indicating that the ligand adopts a thione form in Zn-CP, which is also supported by the FT-IR result. The most remarkable feature of the structure is that the layers of Zn-CP consist of two types which are related to each other through the centrosymmetric center. This feature contributes to a stack of the neighboring layers in the sequence of ABAB··· along a crystallographic c axis. The layer of Zn-CP is simplified to a 3-connected uninodal hcb topology with a point symbol of {63} (d) In addition, the packing structure is stabilized by the interlayer weak hydrogen bonds between H-donors of pyridine rings and uncoordinated thione sulfur atoms (C12H···S1) with a distance of 3.713(4) Å and π···π interactions between the centroid of pyridine rings and oxadiazole rings with a distance of 3.447(2) Å, giving rise to a 3D supramolecular motif of a Zn-CP (c and Figure S1).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of [Zn(pzt)2] n  or Zn-CP

A single-crystal X-ray crystallographic analysis demonstrates that Zn-CP crystallizes in the monoclinic system with C2/c space group. The crystal data and the refinement details of Zn-CP are given in . There are one Zn(II) ion and two deprotonated Hpzt ligands in the asymmetric unit. As shown in a, each Zn(II) resides in a tetrahedral ZnN4 geometry that is constructed from two pyridyl nitrogen atoms and two oxadiazole N-donors from four individual pzt ligands with average Zn-N distances of 1.978(3)-2.000(3) and 2.034(3)-2.054(3) Å for Zn-Noxa and Zn-Npy, respectively. The adjacent Zn(II) ions are bridged by two μ2-pzt ligands, resulting in 14-membered ring of the Zn(II) dinuclear unit. Each dinuclear unit is further connected by four adjacent units via four μ2-pzt ligands, generating a 2D layer of Zn-CP in a crystallographic ab plane (b). The shortest Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn separation within the layers is 7.7229(8) Å. It is intriguingly observed that each pzt displays a similar coordination mode, adopting a bidentate bridging mode of μ2-η1(Noxa):η1(Npy) with dihedral angles between the pyridine and oxadiazole planes of 9.94(11) and 5.07(12) Å. The C-S bond lengths of pzt (C2S1 = 1.661(4) Å and C9S1 = 1.667(4) Å) are shorter than that of the thiolate pzt anion, indicating that the ligand adopts a thione form in Zn-CP, which is also supported by the FT-IR result. The most remarkable feature of the structure is that the layers of Zn-CP consist of two types which are related to each other through the centrosymmetric center. This feature contributes to a stack of the neighboring layers in the sequence of ABAB⋅⋅⋅ along a crystallographic c axis. The layer of Zn-CP is simplified to a 3-connected uninodal hcb topology with a point symbol of {63} (d) In addition, the packing structure is stabilized by the interlayer weak hydrogen bonds between H-donors of pyridine rings and uncoordinated thione sulfur atoms (C12H⋅⋅⋅S1) with a distance of 3.713(4) Å and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions between the centroid of pyridine rings and oxadiazole rings with a distance of 3.447(2) Å, giving rise to a 3D supramolecular motif of a Zn-CP (c and Figure S1).

elements.content: displays two different pathways for the synthesis of Zn-CP. The microstructure of Zn-CP was simply prepared by ultrasonic irradiation in aqueous media at ambient temperature within 30 min. The effects of two synthetic parameters, including the mole ratio of an additive pyridine acting as either a modulator or the deprotonating reagent, and the sonication time on their size and morphology were investigated ().
elements.clean_text:
Size and Morphology Variation in the Sonochemical Synthesis of Zn-CP

  displays two different pathways for the synthesis of Zn-CP. The microstructure of Zn-CP was simply prepared by ultrasonic irradiation in aqueous media at ambient temperature within 30 min. The effects of two synthetic parameters, including the mole ratio of an additive pyridine acting as either a modulator or the deprotonating reagent, and the sonication time on their size and morphology were investigated ().

elements.content: The scanning electron microscope (SEM) images demonstrate the altered size and morphology of the Zn-CPs under different synthetic conditions (). A different crystallite size and morphology were observed after the addition of a pyridine as a modulator. The pyridine contains a donor functionality similar to that of the Hpzt ligand. Therefore, the pyridine acts as a modulating competitive ligand at the Zn­(II) sites for reducing the crystalline size and also acts as a base for deprotonating Hpzt. Consequently, the crystal nucleation and growth rates via both coordination and deprotonation equilibria are influenced by this additive compound. For a modulating competitive process, by varying the concentration of pyridine with a constant sonication time for 30 min, the large Zn-CP microplates with an agglomeration and the impurity phase in the product (No. 1) were observed upon adding the lowest amount of pyridine (0.1 mmol) (a). The impurity phase was confirmed by PXRD and FT-IR (Figures S2 and S3). This result may be due to an insufficient amount of pyridine additive for accelerating the deprotonation and nucleation growth rates. According to b, when the amount of pyridine rose to 0.2 mmol, a smaller size of the product (No. 2) was obtained, showing a uniform plate-shaped microstructure of Zn-CP. The agglomeration in a product (No. 3) was observed upon adding 0.3 mmol of pyridine (c). As shown in d,e, when the amount of pyridine was increased to 0.4 and 0.5 mmol, nonuniform size and shape of the products (Nos. 4 and 5) were observed. The excess pyridine may possibly induce very fast nucleation and growth rates, resulting in the formation of a nonuniform crystalline shape. After that, an agglomeration of the nonuniform structure was continuously generated. Therefore, the optimal amount of pyridine was consequently thought to be 0.2 mmol, and the next parameters were studied with this ratio.

elements.content: In addition, without applying an ultrasonic irradiation or without adding a pyridine during the sonication for 30 min, the Zn-CP product was not observed because the Hpzt ligand must be deprotonated and the ultrasonic irradiation provides an extreme condition driving chemically active Zn­(II) and deprotonated pzt in the synthetic reaction. Thus, the combination of a modulating pyridine and ultrasonic irradiation can accelerate the rates of nucleation and growth, which induces the formation of the Zn-CP within a few minutes. To confirm the effect of both modulator and base on the decrease of a crystallite size, potassium hydroxide (KOH) serving as the only base was added. As expected, when 0.2 mmol of KOH was added instead of pyridine in the synthetic condition of sample No. 2, a nonuniform larger size of plates was observed (f). This indicates that effects of both the modulator and deprotonating reagent play a crucial role in the reduction of the crystallite size.

elements.content: In order to investigate the effect of sonication time on size and morphology, the reaction times were varied with the same amount of pyridine (). There are uniform Zn-CP microplates with a good size distribution for sample No. 2 (b,c). In comparison with sample No. 2, the smaller size of the microstructure and the agglomerated morphology of sample No. 6 were found upon decreasing the reaction time to 15 min (a). In addition, larger Zn-CP microplates were observed when the sonication time was extended over 30 min (60 and 90 min) (d,e). These results indicate that the agglomeration of Zn-CP microplates was prevented by the growth of crystalline size upon increasing the ultrasonic reaction time. Consequently, the optimal condition of product No. 2 was selected to be the best uniform size and morphology of the Zn-CP with an average size of 0.38 μm (); then it was selected for luminescent sensing applications.

elements.content: The FT-IR spectra of the bulk products and uniform microplates of Zn-CPs prepared by the solvothermal and sonochemical methods are indistinguishable (). The IR spectra of both products show the characteristic peaks of ν­(CN), ν­(N–N), νas(C–OC), νs(C–OC), ν­(CS), and pyridine in the pzt ligand at 1610, 1050, 1173, 1123, 944, and 688 cm–1, respectively. In comparison with the free Hpzt ligand, the shifted spectra in ν­(N–N) and the shift in the vibration of the pyridine ring to lower energy are attributed to the coordination of oxadiazole and pyridyl nitrogen atoms to the Zn­(II) center. The positive shift of 43 cm–1 in the vibration of thioamide suggests a change of the C–S to CS during the crystallization process, implying that the pzt displays the thione form in the Zn-CP (Scheme S1). This result agrees with the result of X-ray structure analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Characterizations and Thermal Properties

The FT-IR spectra of the bulk products and uniform microplates of Zn-CPs prepared by the solvothermal and sonochemical methods are indistinguishable (). The IR spectra of both products show the characteristic peaks of ν(CN), ν(N-N), νas(C-OC), νs(C-OC), ν(CS), and pyridine in the pzt ligand at 1610, 1050, 1173, 1123, 944, and 688 cm-1, respectively. In comparison with the free Hpzt ligand, the shifted spectra in ν(N-N) and the shift in the vibration of the pyridine ring to lower energy are attributed to the coordination of oxadiazole and pyridyl nitrogen atoms to the Zn(II) center. The positive shift of 43 cm-1 in the vibration of thioamide suggests a change of the C-S to CS during the crystallization process, implying that the pzt displays the thione form in the Zn-CP (Scheme S1). This result agrees with the result of X-ray structure analysis.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses of Zn-CP were carried out to confirm the phase purity of Zn-CP. The XRD patterns of as-synthesized bulk and Zn-CP microplates () are identical with the simulated pattern that was obtained by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. This indicates that the Zn-CP microplates were successfully synthesized with a good crystalline phase purity. The broad XRD peaks of the Zn-CP prepared by the sonochemical method imply the microscale of the as-synthesized Zn-CP. The elemental analysis for the Zn-CP microplates (No. 2) further confirmed the phase purity that was found to be C 39.48, H 1.90, and N 19.16%, agreeing with those of the calculation.

elements.content: In order to determine the thermal stability, thermal gravimetric analyses of both the bulk product and Zn-CP microstructure were performed between 30 and 800 °C under nitrogen gas. As shown in , the thermograms of the bulk product show a high thermal stability up to 320 °C. After that, the organic ligand was decomposed. In contrast, the decomposition of Zn-CP microplates (sample No. 2) initially started at 210 °C, showing that they are less stable than the bulk. This is attributed to the higher surface to volume ratio of the Zn-CP microstructure; also the bulk product needs a higher temperature for collapse of the crystal lattice.

elements.content: As the π-conjugated multidentate ligands and complexes containing d10 metal ions commonly possess strong photoluminescent (PL) properties, the solid-state emission of the free Hpzt ligand and Zn-CP microplates were studied at room temperature (). Upon excitation at 362 nm, the free Hpzt ligand shows an emission maximum at 526 nm, which is attributed to a π* to n or a π* to π transition. When the coordinated pzt was incorporated with Zn­(II) ions, the important photoluminescent property of Zn-CP microplates was observed. The Zn-CP microplates exhibit an intense blue emission band centered at 441 nm upon excitation at 408 nm, which can probably be attributed to a ligand-centered charge transition. In comparison with the pristine Hpzt, a blue shift in the emission band of Zn-CP results from a metal disturbed intraligand transition. The enhanced luminescent intensity of Zn-CP may arise from the strong electronic coupling between the adjacent coordinated pzt ligands through Zn­(II) ions, leading to a reduction of the ligand vibration and nonradiative decay. In addition, the emission of Zn-CP microplates suspended in various solvents was investigated (Figure S6). The result shows that the solvents slightly affect the luminescent intensity of Zn-CP.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Properties

As the π-conjugated multidentate ligands and complexes containing d10 metal ions commonly possess strong photoluminescent (PL) properties, the solid-state emission of the free Hpzt ligand and Zn-CP microplates were studied at room temperature (). Upon excitation at 362 nm, the free Hpzt ligand shows an emission maximum at 526 nm, which is attributed to a π* to n or a π* to π transition. When the coordinated pzt was incorporated with Zn(II) ions, the important photoluminescent property of Zn-CP microplates was observed. The Zn-CP microplates exhibit an intense blue emission band centered at 441 nm upon excitation at 408 nm, which can probably be attributed to a ligand-centered charge transition. In comparison with the pristine Hpzt, a blue shift in the emission band of Zn-CP results from a metal disturbed intraligand transition. The enhanced luminescent intensity of Zn-CP may arise from the strong electronic coupling between the adjacent coordinated pzt ligands through Zn(II) ions, leading to a reduction of the ligand vibration and nonradiative decay. In addition, the emission of Zn-CP microplates suspended in various solvents was investigated (Figure S6). The result shows that the solvents slightly affect the luminescent intensity of Zn-CP.

elements.content: Inspired by the visible luminescent nature of an electron-rich Zn-CP containing many unbound basic sites, Zn-CP was anticipated to enable the selective and sensitive luminescent detection of electron-deficient nitroaromatic compounds (NACs). All luminescence sensing measurements were performed by the dispersion of Zn-CP microplates in an ethanolic media because of the environmentally friendly solvent and the high solubility of NACs in ethanol. In addition, the stability of the luminescent intensity for the Zn-CP suspensions was examined. As depicted in , the luminescent intensity of the ethanolic suspension containing the bulk product of Zn-CP sharply decreased upon increasing the standing time. In contrast, the suspension of Zn-CP microplates prepared by the sonochemical method was slightly reduced in emission intensity with an increase in time. This implies that the luminescent stability of the suspension containing the microscale Zn-CP is better than that of the bulk product. This is attributed to the lower precipitation rate of the microcrystals in the ethanolic suspension. In order to explore the sensing ability of the Zn-CP microplates toward the different NACs, a PL titration was conducted by adding different concentrations of NACs into the Zn-CP suspension. The significant luminescence quenching for 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) was clearly observed in comparison with other NACs (a). The luminescent turn-off signal is also easily distinguished by the naked eye under a UV lamp (b), demonstrating the applicability of Zn-CP for real-time sensing of TNP. On the basis of the quenching efficiency, as calculated from the equation (I 0 – I)/I 0 × 100% (where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities of Zn-CP before and after the addition of the NACs, respectively), TNP shows the highest quenching efficiency at 86.96% with the quenching order TNP ≫ 2,4-DNP > 4-NP > 3-NP > NB > 2,6-DNT > 1,4-DNB > 4-NT > 2,4-DNT, clearly indicating a high selectivity for TNP detection (c). Owing to the specificity of a luminescent probe for NACs in the coexistence of other competing NACs, it is very important in real sample applications. Competitive PL titration experiments were carried out by recording the emission spectra of the Zn-CP suspensions in the presence of other NACs with TNP. As shown in Figure S7, a negligible quenching efficiency of Zn-CP suspensions was observed after the addition of other NACs. This indicates the high specificity of Zn-CP toward TNP recognition, even in the presence of interfering compounds.

Luminescent Sensing of TNP

Inspired by the visible luminescent nature of an electron-rich Zn-CP containing many unbound basic sites, Zn-CP was anticipated to enable the selective and sensitive luminescent detection of electron-deficient nitroaromatic compounds (NACs). All luminescence sensing measurements were performed by the dispersion of Zn-CP microplates in an ethanolic media because of the environmentally friendly solvent and the high solubility of NACs in ethanol. In addition, the stability of the luminescent intensity for the Zn-CP suspensions was examined. As depicted in , the luminescent intensity of the ethanolic suspension containing the bulk product of Zn-CP sharply decreased upon increasing the standing time. In contrast, the suspension of Zn-CP microplates prepared by the sonochemical method was slightly reduced in emission intensity with an increase in time. This implies that the luminescent stability of the suspension containing the microscale Zn-CP is better than that of the bulk product. This is attributed to the lower precipitation rate of the microcrystals in the ethanolic suspension. In order to explore the sensing ability of the Zn-CP microplates toward the different NACs, a PL titration was conducted by adding different concentrations of NACs into the Zn-CP suspension. The significant luminescence quenching for 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) was clearly observed in comparison with other NACs (a). The luminescent turn-off signal is also easily distinguished by the naked eye under a UV lamp (b), demonstrating the applicability of Zn-CP for real-time sensing of TNP. On the basis of the quenching efficiency, as calculated from the equation (I 0 - I)/I 0 × 100% (where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities of Zn-CP before and after the addition of the NACs, respectively), TNP shows the highest quenching efficiency at 86.96% with the quenching order TNP ≫ 2,4-DNP > 4-NP > 3-NP > NB > 2,6-DNT > 1,4-DNB > 4-NT > 2,4-DNT, clearly indicating a high selectivity for TNP detection (c). Owing to the specificity of a luminescent probe for NACs in the coexistence of other competing NACs, it is very important in real sample applications. Competitive PL titration experiments were carried out by recording the emission spectra of the Zn-CP suspensions in the presence of other NACs with TNP. As shown in Figure S7, a negligible quenching efficiency of Zn-CP suspensions was observed after the addition of other NACs. This indicates the high specificity of Zn-CP toward TNP recognition, even in the presence of interfering compounds.

elements.content: To test the sensitivity, a Stern–Volmer (S-V) plot following I 0/I = 1 + K SV[TNP], where I 0 and I are the luminescent intensities of the suspensions of Zn-CP before and after the addition of TNP, respectively, K SV is the quenching constant (M–1), and [TNP] is the molar concentration of TNP, was performed by the addition of different concentrations of TNP to the Zn-CP suspensions (a). The luminescent intensity of Zn-CP suspension gradually decreases, and slightly red shifted emission spectra were observed upon an increase in the TNP concentration. The shifted spectrum may be caused by the resonance energy transfer mechanism occurring between TNP and Zn-CP. A quenching efficiency of 14.37% was observed upon reaching 5 μM of TNP, suggesting a high sensitivity. After fitting to the S–V equation, the best linear fitting (R 2) is 0.9987 at a lower TNP concentration that is attributed to either static or dynamic quenching. The K SV value for TNP was fitted to be 3.84 × 104 M–1 from the linear curve, indicating the strong interaction between TNP and Zn-CP microplates. Upon an increase in the concentration of TNP, a nonlinear S-V plot was observed, which may be ascribed to a self-absorption or an occurrence of an energy transfer process between TNP and Zn-CP (b). The limit of detection (LOD) of TNP was calculated to be 0.19 μM (Table S2 and Figure S8). On the other hand, in comparison with the bulk product of the Zn-CP obtained from the solvothermal method, the bulk product shows a lower K SV (2.45 × 104 M–1) with a higher LOD of 0.40 μM (91.67 ppb) for TNP (Figures S9 and S10 and Table S3). This result indicates that the Zn-CP microplates prepared by the sonochemical method can improve the sensitivity for TNP sensing. This is attributed to the higher dispersibility of the microstructures in the suspension and also the greater number of accessible active sites on their surface leading to the strong interaction between TNP and the Zn-CP layers. The large K SV value and the low LOD of the Zn-CP microplates for TNP are comparable with those of other reported luminescent CP probes (Table S4), which make a Zn-CP a good candidate for a chemosensor of TNP.

elements.content: Furthermore, to investigate the response time of the Zn-CP suspension toward TNP sensing, the luminescent intensity after addition of three different concentrations of TNP to the suspensions was monitored as a function of exposure time. The result shows that the Zn-CP suspension takes only a few seconds (<30 s) to achieve a high quenching efficiency and then maintains an equilibrium (Figure S11). The recyclability of Zn-CP microplates was also investigated. Zn-CP microplates can be recovered by centrifuging the suspension after use and then washing several times with EtOH. As illustrated in a, five recovery cycles for the Zn-CP suspension were conducted without an intensity loss, implying a high reusability for practical applications. Also, the crystallinity and the structural integrity of the Zn-CP microplates were well preserved, as confirmed by the PXRD patterns being identical with that of an as-synthesized product (b).

Also, the crystallinity and the structural integrity of the Zn-CP microplates were well preserved, as confirmed by the PXRD patterns being identical with that of an as-synthesized product (b).

elements.content: The maximum quenching efficiency for TNP may be attributed to a photoinduced electron transfer (PET) mechanism from the electron-rich Zn-CP to the electron-deficient TNP that corresponds to the lowest LUMO energy of TNP in comparison with those of NACs. Moreover, a significant overlap between the absorption band of TNP and the emission band of luminophore Zn-CPs with a subsequently small overlap of 2,4-DNP were also observed (Figure S12). The others exhibit no spectral overlaps. Therefore, the significant spectral overlap for TNP provides evidence for a resonance energy transfer mechanism (RET), resulting in the highly selective quenching response. This mechanism is also supported by the red-shifted luminescent intensity and the nonlinearity of the S–V plot at high concentrations of TNP (). In addition, the quenching efficiency shows the order TNP ≫ 2,4-DNP > 4-NP, correlating well with the order of their acidity. Thus, the molecular interaction between the acidic hydroxyl group of NACs and the uncoordinated basic sites including pyridyl nitrogen, thione, and oxadiazole of pzt in Zn-CP also play a key role in the selectivity. Consequently, the strongest interaction between the most highly acidic hydroxyl group on TNP and the uncoordinated basic sites in Zn-CP effectively induces favorable energy transfer and electron transfer processes, leading to the amplified selectivity and sensitive quenching response of TNP in this system.

elements.content: A new Zn­(II) coordination network containing various unbound basic sites was synthesized by solvothermal and sonochemical methods. The uniform size and shape of the Zn-CP microstructures were achieved by optimizing both the concentration of the modulator and the sonication time under mild ultrasonic conditions in aqueous media. The Zn-CP suspension in ethanol facilitates the luminescent sensing of NACs with highly selective quenching for TNP without the interference of other NACs. Moreover, a low detection limit, high quenching constant, and fast response for TNP were observed, implying a high sensitivity and strong interaction toward TNP. The quenching process occurs through energy and electron transfer mechanisms, along with molecular interactions between Zn-CP and TNP.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A new Zn(II) coordination network containing various unbound basic sites was synthesized by solvothermal and sonochemical methods. The uniform size and shape of the Zn-CP microstructures were achieved by optimizing both the concentration of the modulator and the sonication time under mild ultrasonic conditions in aqueous media. The Zn-CP suspension in ethanol facilitates the luminescent sensing of NACs with highly selective quenching for TNP without the interference of other NACs. Moreover, a low detection limit, high quenching constant, and fast response for TNP were observed, implying a high sensitivity and strong interaction toward TNP. The quenching process occurs through energy and electron transfer mechanisms, along with molecular interactions between Zn-CP and TNP.

cln_elements.content:
The bulk crystals and a single crystal of Zn-CP were prepared by mixing Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0297 g, 0.1 mmol) and Hpzt (0.0178 g, 0.1 mmol) in 4 mL of H2O/ACN/DMF (1/2/1 mL). The solution mixture was placed in a 20 mL glass vial and then sealed and heated at 90 °C for 16 h to obtain pale yellow crystals of Zn-CP. Yield: 0.0117 g, 49.3% (based on Hpzt). Anal. Calcd for ZnC14H8N6O2S2 (fw = 421.75): C, 39.87; H, 1.91; N, 19.93. Found: C, 39.42; H, 1.64; N, 19.62. FT-IR (ATR, cm–1): 1610 (w), 1173 (s), 1123 (w), 1050 (m), 944 (m), 688 (s).

Sonochemical Synthesis of [Zn­(pzt)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (Zn-CP)

To prepare a micro-sized Zn-CP, Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0297 g, 0.1 mmol) and Hpzt (0.0178 g, 0.1 mmol) were mixed with 6 mL of water containing the pyridine. The mixture was positioned in an ultrasonic bath, operating at 50 Hz with a maximum power output of 280 W, under atmospheric pressure and ambient temperature. The amount of pyridine and sonication time were varied following the synthetic conditions, as summarized in . After the sonication process, a pale yellow polycrystal of Zn-CP was obtained. Then, the product was filtered off and washed with ethanol to remove the pyridine and dried in the air.

The bulk crystals and a single crystal of Zn-CP were prepared by mixing Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0297 g, 0.1 mmol) and Hpzt (0.0178 g, 0.1 mmol) in 4 mL of H2O/ACN/DMF (1/2/1 mL). The solution mixture was placed in a 20 mL glass vial and then sealed and heated at 90 °C for 16 h to obtain pale yellow crystals of Zn-CP. Yield: 0.0117 g, 49.3% (based on Hpzt). Anal. Calcd for ZnC14H8N6O2S2 (fw = 421.75): C, 39.87; H, 1.91; N, 19.93. Found: C, 39.42; H, 1.64; N, 19.62. FT-IR (ATR, cm-1): 1610 (w), 1173 (s), 1123 (w), 1050 (m), 944 (m), 688 (s).

Sonochemical Synthesis of [Zn(pzt)2] n  (Zn-CP)

To prepare a micro-sized Zn-CP, Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0297 g, 0.1 mmol) and Hpzt (0.0178 g, 0.1 mmol) were mixed with 6 mL of water containing the pyridine. The mixture was positioned in an ultrasonic bath, operating at 50 Hz with a maximum power output of 280 W, under atmospheric pressure and ambient temperature. The amount of pyridine and sonication time were varied following the synthetic conditions, as summarized in . After the sonication process, a pale yellow polycrystal of Zn-CP was obtained. Then, the product was filtered off and washed with ethanol to remove the pyridine and dried in the air.

cln_elements.content:
In order to determine the thermal stability, thermal gravimetric analyses of both the bulk product and Zn-CP microstructure were performed between 30 and 800 °C under nitrogen gas. As shown in , the thermograms of the bulk product show a high thermal stability up to 320 °C. After that, the organic ligand was decomposed. In contrast, the decomposition of Zn-CP microplates (sample No. 2) initially started at 210 °C, showing that they are less stable than the bulk. This is attributed to the higher surface to volume ratio of the Zn-CP microstructure; also the bulk product needs a higher temperature for collapse of the crystal lattice.

Photoluminescence Properties

As the π-conjugated multidentate ligands and complexes containing d10 metal ions commonly possess strong photoluminescent (PL) properties, the solid-state emission of the free Hpzt ligand and Zn-CP microplates were studied at room temperature (). Upon excitation at 362 nm, the free Hpzt ligand shows an emission maximum at 526 nm, which is attributed to a π* to n or a π* to π transition. When the coordinated pzt was incorporated with Zn­(II) ions, the important photoluminescent property of Zn-CP microplates was observed. The Zn-CP microplates exhibit an intense blue emission band centered at 441 nm upon excitation at 408 nm, which can probably be attributed to a ligand-centered charge transition. In comparison with the pristine Hpzt, a blue shift in the emission band of Zn-CP results from a metal disturbed intraligand transition. The enhanced luminescent intensity of Zn-CP may arise from the strong electronic coupling between the adjacent coordinated pzt ligands through Zn­(II) ions, leading to a reduction of the ligand vibration and nonradiative decay. In addition, the emission of Zn-CP microplates suspended in various solvents was investigated (Figure S6). The result shows that the solvents slightly affect the luminescent intensity of Zn-CP.
